question: 2 (a)
sols_html:
A picture is included below.

First, we determine the points of intersection. Setting the two curves equal to each other, we have

\[\begin{aligned} 4-x^{2} = (x-2)^{2} = x^{2}-4x + 4\end{aligned}\]

Bringing the terms to the right hand side, we have

\[\begin{aligned} 0 = 2x^{2}-4x = 2x(x-2)\end{aligned}\]

and so the points of intersection are \(x = 0\) and \(x=2\). Notice either form the picture or testing a point between 0 and 2 (say \(x=1\)) and plugging it into both equations, we see that the curve \(4-x^{2}\) is bigger between 0 and 2. Hence, our area is

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{2} (4-x^{2} - (x-2)^{2})\, dx &= \int_{0}^{2} (4-x^{2} - x^{2} + 4x - 4)\, dx \\ &= \int_{0}^{2} (-2x^{2} + 4x)\, dx \\ &= \left.\frac{-2x^{3}}{3} + 2x^{2}\right|_{0}^{2} \\ &= \frac{-2(2)^{3}}{3} + 2(2)^{2}\\ &= \frac{8}{3}\end{aligned}\]

completing the question.
